repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Public Sector Management
            Adjustment Loan Project, Macedonia - Second Public Sector
            Management Adjustment Loan Project, and Slovak Republic -
            Public Finance Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Sector Management
            Adjustment Loan (PSMAL) Project for Macedonia are as
            follows: outcome was moderately unsatisfactory; risk to the
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and Borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Second Public Sector
            Management Adjustment Loan Project for Macedonia are as
            follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk to the
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Public Finance Management
            Project for Slovak Republic are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was low or
            negligible; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned include:
            although differences dominated similarities in the three
            projects, the one common factor that had a determining
            influence on outcomes was the extent of government
            commitment to the projects. Sound analytical work was
            necessary but not sufficient for project success. All three
            projects were based on sound analytical work and they
            matched government strategy. In the case of the Public
            Finance Management Project (PFMP) there was a hand-in-glove
            match between analytical work and government strategy, as
            the government adopted the full recommendations of the
            Development Policy Review. Concentrating on core elements
            was a factor contributing to success. Compared with the
            PFMP, the other two projects over-reached in their ambitions
            to achieve rather wide development policy goals. In the
            main, introducing elements that were outside the purview of
            the budget, such as health and pension reform, affected the
            efficacy of these two operations and prevented them from
            fully realizing their goals. Finally, when the different
            elements of a project fit together well, the project has a
            greater probability of success. The different elements of
            the PFMP fit each other better with one another than those
            of either the Public Sector Management Credit (PSMAC) or the
            PSMAL and were not as widely dispersed as the two Former
            Yugoslav Republic (FYR) Macedonia operations.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Public Sector Management
            Adjustment Loan Project : second tranche release - full compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The document summarizes progress made
            under a reform program supported by the Public Sector
            Management Adjustment Loan (PSMAL) for Macedonia. The
            principal objective of the PSMAL was to improve public
            sector management in order to provide the basis for
            sustained economic growth, and improve the living conditions
            for the country's poor. While addressing a broad range
            of generic issues of public sector management, the PSMAL
            focused specifically on the management of health care
            expenditures, which are both a source of fiscal risk and a
            key element of the Government's effort to reduce
            poverty. In view of the overall performance and progress
            with the implementation of the program supported by the
            Loan, and in compliance with the specific conditions of
            release referred to in Section 2.02 (d) of the Loan
            Agreement, and described in the attached Tranche Release
            Document, it is recommended that the Bank release the second
            tranche of US$ 19.85 million to the Borrower.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Public Sector Management
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that at first
            glance, the Public Sector Management Adjustment Loan (PSMAC)
            experience would appear to confirm the familiar adage that
            Government commitment is essential to reform-and that
            reforms should not be attempted where Government commitment
            is lacking. If these lessons had been observed the PSMAC
            would never have been attempted. No management reforms would
            have been discussed until at least January 2003 and the most
            politically controversial reforms--particularly in civil
            service and health care--would still remain off the reform
            agenda. In retrospect, the PSMAL experience suggests a more
            nuanced set of lessons. It suggests that while unanimous
            Government support for reform is desirable, Bank efforts
            should not be delayed until it exists. The PSMAC also
            supports the case for programmatic adjustment lending.
            Although the follow-on operations (PSMAL, PSAL1 and PSAL2)
            are structured as independent operations, they provide a
            means to ensure that reforms introduced under the PSMAC are
            sustained and extended.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia - Public Sector Management
            Adjustment Credit (PSMAC) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Management Adjustment
            Credit Project aims at laying the foundation for sustained
            economic growth, and improved service delivery in key social
            sectors, and, seeks to build key institutions, strengthen
            accountability, and efficiency of public resources, and prod
            a sustaining macroeconomic stability, and fiscal discipline.
            The main objectives of the project are to: 1) strengthen
            capacity at the center of Government, to implement reforms;
            2) strengthen fiscal discipline within a strong
            accountability, and transparency framework, 3) improve
            strategic prioritization within a fiscal plan; 4) improve
            the efficiency in program, and service delivery in the
            medium-term; and, 5) seek a merit, and performance based
            civil service, capable of supporting the reform strategy.
            Sustainable fiscal budget commitments, and policy
            implementation, will be accomplished through new legislation
            governing the issuance of Government guarantees, and
            accountable policy formulation. Nonetheless, the security
            crisis risks an ensured macroeconomic, and fiscal stability,
            though implementation of the Framework Agreement should test
            the Government's capacity to implement the program.
            Also, the risk of policy reversal, will be minimized by
            ensuring that approval of lending operations only occurs
            once substantial prior actions have been undertaken, and,
            that substantial technical assistance supports reforms
            comprised in the adjustment lending.
